writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?
story:
Neal Caffrey had always been a man of reflection. In the quiet moments between cases, he'd often find himself drifting back to the days when he was just a step ahead of the law, a ghost in the art world's underbelly. As an FBI consultant, the thrill was different now, yet still palpable. The adrenaline, the chase—it was all there, just on the other side of the moral line. But today, sitting in his modestly furnished apartment, he found himself staring at the past more intently than usual.

The proposal had come out of nowhere. An old partner from his forgery days, someone he had once trusted implicitly, had reached out with a heist that was more than just lucrative—it was practically a blank check. But something about it felt... wrong. The details were too vague, the target too high-profile. It reeked of desperation or worse, a setup.

Neal knew better than to fall for such traps, but the allure was undeniable. He had spent years perfecting his craft, creating art that could fool the experts, and now he was using that very expertise to catch criminals like his former self. The irony was not lost on him.

As he pondered the proposal, the familiar ding of his doorbell pulled him from his reverie. He opened the door to find Peter Burke, his FBI handler and, surprisingly, a friend who had become a constant in his tumultuous life.

"Hey, Neal," Peter greeted, stepping inside without waiting for an invitation. "You look like you've seen a ghost."

"Something like that," Neal replied, forcing a smile. "What brings you here?"

Peter gave him a scrutinizing look, the kind that always made Neal feel like he was under a microscope. "Thought I'd check in on you. You've been quiet lately. Everything okay?"

Neal hesitated, the weight of the proposal pressing down on him. "Just... thinking about the past."

"Ah, the past," Peter said, nodding knowingly. "It's a tricky thing, isn't it? Always there, always whispering in your ear."

Neal chuckled, though it lacked genuine amusement. "Yeah, something like that."

Peter's eyes narrowed slightly. "You know, Neal, if there's something on your mind, you can talk to me. We're partners, remember?"

The word 'partners' struck a chord. It had been years since Neal had considered anyone a true partner, at least not in the criminal sense. But with Peter, it was different. There was a trust there, a respect that had been hard-earned.

"Actually, there is something," Neal admitted, running a hand through his hair. "I got a message from an old acquaintance. He proposed a heist."

Peter's expression hardened. "Are you considering it?"

Neal shook his head. "No, but... it made me think. Have I really changed, or am I just fooling myself?"

Peter sighed, leaning against the counter. "Neal, change isn't easy. It's not a straight path. You've come a long way from the guy I first chased down. But the fact that you're hesitating, questioning it—that's a good sign. It means you're not that same person anymore."

Neal wanted to believe him, but doubt lingered. "What if it's just a matter of time before I slip?"

Peter placed a hand on his shoulder, a rare gesture of camaraderie. "It's not about never slipping. It's about getting back up and choosing the right path again. You're doing that, every day."

The reassurance was comforting, but Neal knew the real test was yet to come. He had to confront his old partner, put an end to the temptation once and for all. 

The next day, Neal met his old partner in a quiet, secluded park. The man looked the same, yet different—more desperate, less assured.

"Neal," he greeted, a sly smile on his lips. "Glad you decided to meet."

"I'm here to tell you no," Neal said firmly. "I'm out of that life."

The smile faltered. "Come on, Neal. One last job. For old times' sake."

Neal shook his head. "No. This isn't who I am anymore."

The man's eyes darkened. "You've changed."

"Yes, I have," Neal replied, feeling a sense of finality. "And you should too."

With that, Neal turned and walked away, leaving his old life behind. He felt a weight lift off his shoulders, a clarity he hadn't felt in years.

Back at the FBI office, Peter was waiting. Neal gave him a nod, a silent acknowledgment of the journey he was on.

"Ready to catch some bad guys?" Peter asked, a grin spreading across his face.

"Always," Neal replied, smiling back. He knew the road ahead wouldn't be easy, but for the first time, he felt confident in the path he had chosen. And with Peter by his side, he knew he could face whatever came next.

writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.
story:
Crowley was not one for nostalgia. A demon of his stature had no need for sentimental journeys through the annals of his past. Yet, here he was, sitting in a dimly lit dive bar, nursing a glass of whiskey, and reminiscing about his time with Dean Winchester.

Years had passed since their last encounter. The King of Hell had never imagined he'd cross paths with the hunter again. But fate, with its twisted sense of humor, had other plans. When Dean walked into the bar, Crowley's heart—had it still been capable of human emotions—might have skipped a beat.

"Well, if it isn't Squirrel," Crowley drawled, raising his glass in a mock toast.

Dean's eyes widened in surprise before a slow smirk spread across his face. "Crowley. Fancy meeting you here."

The ensuing conversation was a dance of wary familiarity, each man gauging the other's intentions. Yet, beneath the surface, there was an undercurrent of unspoken words and unresolved feelings. As the night wore on, the bar's patrons dwindled, leaving them in a cocoon of shadows and memories.

"You know, I never thought I'd see you again," Dean confessed, his voice tinged with a vulnerability that Crowley had rarely heard.

Crowley leaned back, studying the hunter. "Life has a funny way of bringing people back together, doesn't it?"

Dean chuckled, taking a sip of his beer. "Yeah, guess so."

Their conversation meandered through the years they'd spent apart, touching on old battles and new scars. It was in the quiet moments between words that Crowley felt the weight of his own loneliness. For all his power and cunning, he had never found a connection quite like the one he had with Dean.

As the night deepened, Dean's confessions grew bolder. He spoke of the emptiness that had followed him since their last encounter, the hollow victories and the fleeting moments of peace. Crowley listened, his heart aching for the man who had once been his reluctant ally.

"Do you ever regret it?" Dean asked, his voice barely a whisper. "All the things we didn't say?"

Crowley sighed, his gaze fixed on the amber liquid in his glass. "Regret is a human luxury, darling. But if I were to indulge...yes, I do."

Dean's eyes searched Crowley's face, seeking the truth behind the words. In that moment, the walls between them crumbled, leaving only the raw, unfiltered reality of their feelings.

Without a word, Dean leaned in, capturing Crowley's lips in a kiss that spoke of years of longing and unspoken desire. Crowley responded in kind, the fire between them igniting once more. The kiss was a promise of what could be, a testament to the bond that had never truly broken.

Their stolen kisses became a nightly ritual, a sanctuary from the chaos of their lives. But their rekindled relationship was not without its challenges. The life of a demon and a hunter was fraught with danger, and their newfound connection drew the attention of federal agents.

Crowley had always been a master of deception, but even he found it difficult to navigate the labyrinth of lies and half-truths that their relationship demanded. Dean, ever the stubborn protector, took it upon himself to shield Crowley from prying eyes, even if it meant putting himself at risk.

Their lives became a tangled web of secrets and close calls, yet amidst the tension, there were moments of startling normalcy. Family barbecues at the Winchester's bunker became a cherished tradition, a brief respite from their tumultuous existence.

Crowley found himself surprisingly at ease in the presence of Dean's family. Sam, ever the watchful brother, had initially been wary of Crowley's intentions. But over time, he came to see the genuine affection between the demon and his brother.

It was during one such barbecue, as the sun dipped below the horizon, casting a warm glow over the gathering, that Crowley realized how much his life had changed. The laughter of friends and family, the scent of grilled meat, and the feel of Dean's hand in his—these were the moments that made the struggles worth it.

As the night drew to a close, Crowley and Dean found themselves alone, the soft murmur of conversation fading into the background. Dean looked at Crowley, his eyes filled with a quiet determination.

"Whatever happens, we'll face it together," Dean said, his voice unwavering.

Crowley smiled, a rare, genuine smile that reached his eyes. "Together, then."

In that moment, Crowley knew that some things were indeed worth rewriting the plan for. The life they had built, with its late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and tangled adventures, was more than he had ever dared to hope for. And for once, the King of Hell was content.

writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.
story:
Neal Caffrey leaned back in his chair, the faint hum of the FBI office around him a familiar backdrop to his musings. He often found himself reflecting on the strange twists his life had taken—how he had gone from a con artist, perpetually on the run, to an FBI consultant, solving crimes rather than committing them. It was a role he had grown into, although not without its share of irony. Today, however, was shaping up to be particularly ironic.

A heated discussion had been brewing in the office for the past half hour. Peter Burke, his handler and the embodiment of the term 'by-the-book,' stood at the head of the conference table, his brow furrowed in concentration. The case they were working on—a complex forgery involving priceless art—had hit a snag. Evidence had been mishandled, and the legality of their next steps was under intense scrutiny.

"Look, we can't just go barging into the gallery without proper warrants," Peter was saying, his voice firm. "We need to follow protocol."

Neal, who had been quietly observing the debate, felt an unexpected surge of irritation. The old Neal would have relished the chaos, exploiting it to his advantage. But the new Neal—the one who had come to respect the rules, even if he didn't always agree with them—found himself compelled to speak up.

"Peter's right," Neal said, his voice cutting through the clamor. The room fell silent, all eyes turning to him. "We need to do this by the book."

For a moment, there was stunned silence. Then Jones, one of the agents, let out a bark of laughter. "Did I hear that right? Neal Caffrey, defending legal procedures?"

Neal rolled his eyes but couldn't suppress a grin. "I know, I know. But think about it. If we don't follow the proper channels, any evidence we find could be thrown out in court. We can't risk that."

Peter's lips twitched, a rare smile threatening to break through his stern facade. "You heard the man. We do this by the book."

The discussion continued, but the mood had lightened considerably. Neal caught Peter's eye and saw the amusement there. It was moments like these that reminded him how far he'd come—and how much he still had to learn.

Later, as they wrapped up for the day, Peter approached Neal at his desk. "You know, I never thought I'd see the day when you'd be the one preaching about legal procedures."

Neal shrugged, a mischievous glint in his eye. "What can I say? You've been a good influence on me."

Peter chuckled. "Don't think this means I'm going to let you off the hook. I'll be reminding you of this moment for a long time."

Neal smirked. "I wouldn't expect anything less."

As the office emptied out, Neal found himself alone with his thoughts once more. The evidence they had gathered pointed to a well-orchestrated forgery ring, and the gallery in question was the key to unraveling it. He knew they were close, but they had to tread carefully.

He packed up his things, the weight of the day settling on his shoulders. As he made his way to the exit, Peter fell into step beside him.

"Hey, Neal," Peter said, his tone more serious now. "I meant what I said earlier. You've really come a long way."

Neal glanced at him, surprised by the sincerity in his voice. "Thanks, Peter. That means a lot."

They walked out into the cool evening air, the city buzzing with life around them. Neal took a deep breath, savoring the moment. He had spent so many years looking over his shoulder, always one step ahead of the law. Now, he was part of something bigger—something that gave him a sense of purpose he hadn't realized he was missing.

As they headed towards Peter's car, Neal couldn't help but feel a sense of satisfaction. The case was far from over, and there would undoubtedly be more challenges ahead. But for now, he was content. He had found a place where he belonged, and he was determined to make the most of it.

"Ready to call it a night?" Peter asked, unlocking the car.

Neal nodded. "Yeah. Let's get some rest. We've got a busy day ahead."

As they drove away, Neal glanced out the window, the city lights blurring into a kaleidoscope of colors. He had come a long way from the life of a con artist, and while the road ahead was uncertain, he knew one thing for sure: he was exactly where he was meant to be.

writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.
story:
Scotty leaned against the bulkhead, staring at the diagnostic panel with a mix of frustration and determination. The USS Enterprise, pride of Starfleet, was adrift in the void, systems non-responsive, and no clear indication as to why. He had been through every conceivable scenario, checked and rechecked every system, yet the cause of their predicament remained elusive.

The crew had been stranded for hours now, and the situation was growing increasingly desperate. Life support systems were functioning, but without propulsion or navigational controls, they were a sitting duck in the vast emptiness of space. Scotty’s mind raced with possibilities, each more improbable than the last. This ship, his ship, had faced countless dangers and emerged victorious. He would be damned if he let her down now.

"Scotty, any progress?" Captain Kirk's voice crackled over the intercom, a thin veil of hope barely concealing the underlying tension.

"Workin' on it, Cap'n," Scotty replied, his accent thicker with the stress. "I’ve checked every system twice, every relay, every conduit. There’s nae a single thing wrong, yet here we are."

"Understood, Mr. Scott. Keep me posted. Kirk out."

The intercom clicked off, leaving Scotty alone with his thoughts and the low hum of the emergency lights. He knew the crew was relying on him. Kirk’s confidence was unshakable, but even the captain had his limits. They all did.

Sighing, Scotty ran a hand through his hair and returned to the console. "Think, Scotty, think," he muttered to himself. "What’s been overlooked? What’s right under your nose?"

Theories swirled in his mind. A power surge? No, all power readings were within normal parameters. A software glitch? He had already run diagnostics on the ship’s computer more times than he could count. An external force? There had been no signs of interference.

Suddenly, a thought struck him. What if the answer wasn’t in the systems themselves, but in something more fundamental? Something that wouldn’t show up on a diagnostic scan?

"Transporter room, this is Scotty. I need a full diagnostic on the transporter buffers, stat."

"Aye, sir," came the prompt reply.

Minutes ticked by as Scotty continued to pace, the tension mounting with each passing second. He knew the clock was ticking. The crew’s time was running out, and he was their best hope.

"Scotty, we’ve found something," the voice from the transporter room broke through his reverie. "There’s a pattern buffer anomaly. It’s minor, but it’s there."

"A pattern buffer anomaly?" Scotty’s mind raced. The transporters were tied into the ship’s main systems in ways that were complex and often overlooked. An anomaly there could have cascading effects. "I need ye to isolate the buffer and run a level three diagnostic."

"Aye, sir."

The minutes stretched into what felt like an eternity. Scotty could feel the weight of the ship on his shoulders. The Enterprise was more than just a vessel; she was home, and her crew, his family.

"Scotty, we’ve isolated the anomaly. It’s causing feedback loops through the secondary systems. That’s what’s been knockin’ everything offline."

Relief flooded through Scotty, followed swiftly by a renewed sense of urgency. "Good work. I need ye to purge the buffer and reset the system. I’ll coordinate from here."

As he worked, Scotty’s fingers flew over the controls, his mind a blur of calculations and commands. This was what he lived for, the challenge, the puzzle, the chance to save the day. He could feel the Enterprise responding, the systems coming back to life under his touch.

"Captain, this is Scotty. We’ve isolated the problem. Transporter buffer anomaly causing feedback loops. We’re resetting now."

"Good work, Scotty. How long until we’re back online?"

"Just a few more minutes, Cap’n. We’ll have her purrin’ like a kitten."

True to his word, within minutes the systems were back online. The hum of the warp core was music to his ears, a symphony of power and precision. Scotty allowed himself a small smile as he initiated the final sequence.

"All systems operational, Cap’n," he reported. "We’re ready to get underway."

"Excellent work, Mr. Scott," Kirk’s voice was warm with gratitude. "You’ve done it again."

Scotty leaned back, a sense of profound relief washing over him. The crisis was averted, the crew safe. But more than that, he had reaffirmed what he always knew – that the Enterprise, and her crew, were a team unlike any other. Together, they could face any challenge, and come out stronger on the other side.

writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.
story:
Neal Caffrey stared at the stack of audit documents on his desk, the hum of the FBI office around him a distant murmur. His eyes flicked to the clock—3:45 PM. The relentless agent from Internal Affairs, Agent Grayson, had been combing through their files for the past two days, and Neal couldn't shake the feeling that the man was particularly interested in him.

Peter Burke had warned him about Grayson—a stickler for rules, a man who saw the world in black and white. Neal knew that if Grayson found anything remotely suspicious, it wouldn't just be his neck on the line, but Peter's as well. And now, with the shadow of suspicion cast over him for a forgery he didn’t commit, Neal felt the pressure mounting.

Neal leaned back in his chair, allowing his mind to wander through the labyrinth of possibilities. The forgery in question was sophisticated, almost too perfect. It bore the hallmarks of a master, and Neal couldn't help but admire the craftsmanship, even as it put him in jeopardy. But admiration wouldn't clear his name. He needed a plan.

As he pondered, his gaze drifted to Peter’s office, where his friend and handler was locked in a tense conversation with Grayson. Peter’s face was a mask of calm, but Neal could see the strain in his eyes. This wasn’t just about the forgery—it was about trust, loyalty, and the delicate balance they had built over the years.

Neal’s mind raced, his thoughts crystallizing into a plan that was both clever and reckless. He knew the line he was about to walk was razor-thin, but he had no choice. He had to protect Peter and clear his name.

That evening, long after most of the office had gone home, Neal sat at his desk, surrounded by the silence of the empty bullpen. He had gathered everything he needed: a laptop, a few carefully selected tools, and a cup of lukewarm coffee. He glanced around, ensuring he was alone, then set to work.

He accessed the FBI’s internal database, his fingers flying over the keyboard with practiced ease. He wasn’t hacking, exactly—just bending the rules a little. He pulled up the files related to the forgery, cross-referencing them with known forgers and their techniques. It was like assembling a puzzle, each piece falling into place with satisfying precision.

Hours passed, the office bathed in the soft glow of Neal’s desk lamp. He found what he was looking for—a name, a signature style, a trail of breadcrumbs that led him to an old rival, someone who had a grudge against him. Someone who would have every reason to frame him.

Neal’s lips curled into a wry smile. It was almost poetic, in a way. He gathered his findings, compiling them into a neat report. He knew he couldn’t present this directly to Grayson—he had to be smart about it. He needed Peter.

The next morning, Neal waited for Peter outside the office, the early sunlight casting long shadows on the pavement. Peter arrived, looking weary but determined. Neal fell into step beside him, handing over the report without a word.

Peter glanced at the document, then at Neal. “What’s this?”

“Proof,” Neal said simply. “I didn’t do it, Peter. But I know who did.”

Peter’s eyes narrowed as he scanned the report, his jaw tightening. “Neal, if this is some kind of…”

“It’s not,” Neal interrupted. “I swear. This is the real deal. You know I wouldn’t risk everything we’ve built over a forgery.”

Peter studied him for a long moment, then nodded. “Alright. Let’s see what Grayson has to say about this.”

Together, they approached Grayson, who was ensconced in a corner of the bullpen, his expression as unreadable as ever. Peter handed over the report, explaining the situation with calm authority. Grayson’s eyes flicked between Peter and Neal, suspicion lingering, but he took the report and began to read.

The minutes stretched into an eternity as Grayson scrutinized the evidence. Finally, he looked up, his gaze settling on Neal. “This is… compelling,” he admitted grudgingly. “I’ll need to verify it, but if it checks out, it looks like you’re in the clear.”

Relief washed over Neal, but he kept his expression neutral. “Thank you, Agent Grayson.”

As Grayson walked away, Peter turned to Neal, a hint of a smile playing at the corners of his mouth. “Clever work, Neal.”

Neal shrugged, his own smile genuine. “I had to protect my team, Peter. And you.”

Peter clapped a hand on Neal’s shoulder. “I know. And you did. Let’s hope this is the last time.”

Neal nodded, the weight lifting from his shoulders. It wasn’t just about clearing his name—it was about trust, loyalty, and the unspoken bond between them. And for now, that was enough.
